author: Rob Polansky
title: Firefighter on snowplowing route notices house fire, rescues 4 people and 3 dogs
text:
TRUMBULL, Conn. (WFSB/Gray News) - A firefighter who was plowing the snowy streets of Trumbull, Connecticut, jumped into action to rescue four people and three dogs when he happened upon a house fire.
WFSB reports Shaun Bogen’s quick actions were credited with saving the lives of the victims.
The Long Hill Fire Department said the house fire on Haviland Drive began just before 4 a.m. Sunday.
While he was on the plowing route, Bogen discovered a house with a fire in the garage, according to the fire department. Bogen radioed into his base to alert them of the fire and called 911.
Bogen then sprung into action, waking up the four sleeping residents and their three dogs and making sure everyone was outside before the fire department arrived.
A total of 26 firefighters responded to the fire, and the first unit to arrive found the fire most heavy in the garage and extending into the home.
The firefighters brought the fire under control in less than one hour.
Officials said there did not appear to be any injuries.
The cause of the fire remains under investigation.
Copyright 2024 WFSB via Gray Media Group, Inc. All rights reserved.

author: @alonsodelarte
title: The most common passwords of 2024
text:
Some of the world’s most important passwords are about to be entrusted to a criminal who has already clearly shown us he does not deserve that trust. You wouldn’t give Trump your online banking password, but we’re supposed to give him the nuclear codes?
Maybe someone who would choose “123456” for his password would also be gullible enough to think that Donald Trump is a brilliant businessman who cares about you, not they/them. Though to be fair, the last time I wrote about password security, I did suggest tiers of password security: strong passwords for things like online banking, weak passwords for things like Pandora Radio.
Well, it’s that time of year again, when NordPass tells us the most commonly used passwords of the year. Gael Cooper for CNET:
"'123456' has once again claimed the title of the world's worst password!" the NordPass analysis reports. "In fact, during this our six-year study, it topped the charts as the most common password 5 out of 6 times. 'Password' held this not-so-noble title just once." Here are the top five passwords for personal accounts, according to the analysis. 123456 123456789 12345678 password qwerty123 And here are the top five for corporate accounts. 123456 123456789 12345678 secret password According to the report, it takes less than a second to crack any of these 10 passwords. The company reviewed and analyzed a 2.5TB database extracted from public sources, including those on the dark web. Data was organized by country of origin, covering 44 countries, and was separated by corporate and personal credentials by the use of related email addresses.
"'123456' has once again claimed the title of the world's worst password!" the NordPass analysis reports. "In fact, during this our six-year study, it topped the charts as the most common password 5 out of 6 times. 'Password' held this not-so-noble title just once."
Here are the top five passwords for personal accounts, according to the analysis.
And here are the top five for corporate accounts.
According to the report, it takes less than a second to crack any of these 10 passwords.
The company reviewed and analyzed a 2.5TB database extracted from public sources, including those on the dark web. Data was organized by country of origin, covering 44 countries, and was separated by corporate and personal credentials by the use of related email addresses.
If you get clever and use passwords like “drowssap” and “654321” you’re better off, but not by much.

author: Chuck Chiang; The Canadian Press
title: Warm weather wreaks havoc on some B.C. ski hills as lack of snow leaves trails barren
text:
VANCOUVER — British Columbia's abnormally warm winter has left local ski resorts grappling with a lack of snow during the holiday tourism season, as resorts struggle to keep runs open.
Fewer than half of Whistler Blackcomb's trails are open, while Vancouver's Mount Seymour is closed entirely while it waits for better conditions.
Warmth related to the El Niño climate phenomenon this week has pushed temperatures to record highs in regions including Metro Vancouver, Greater Victoria, the Sunshine Coast and the Okanagan.
In Whistler, 120 kilometres north of Vancouver, Environment Canada was reporting no snow on the ground on Christmas Day, compared to 40 centimetres last Christmas.
On Thursday, the Whistler Blackcomb resort reported 117 of its 275 trails were open, as well as only 42 per cent of its terrain.
Warm weather has hit Metro Vancouver's three main ski hills even harder, with Cypress and Grouse mountains operating only one or two runs each.
Mount Seymour closed entirely on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday, pending more snow.
James Shalman, general manager at Apex Mountain Resort in the Okanagans, says resorts across the province are "definitely behind the 8-ball" because of the warm weather, with visitors lost during the holidays unlikely to return later in the season.
"All resorts in B.C. are very reliant on the Christmas holidays as a significant portion of their financial picture for the season," Shalman said.
"This is not something where you can make up what you're down during Christmas break. You won't make that up later in the season, even if we get amazing snowfall in January, February, March."
Apex on Thursday had about a third of its roughly 79 runs open, a stark contrast from 2022 when every run was open in the first week of December thanks to heavy snowfalls.
Shalman said Apex had significant snow-making capacity and used it to combat the lack of precipitation, but there were weeks this month where the temperatures were too warm to make snow.
"I mean, we are essentially snow farmers," he says. "We're Mother Nature-dependent, and we just have to take what we get."
At Cypress Mountain in West Vancouver, management warned skiers of "thin snow coverage" for what little of the hill was open.
Several resorts have been offering discounted passes and tickets to entice skiers to visit.
"Rain's the star of the show today," Cypress Mountain's update on Thursday said, noting that night skiing had been cancelled.
Environment Canada meteorologist Brian Proctor said that in addition to El Niño, a ridge of high pressure had created a "blocking pattern" across much of North America. That was preventing the warm air generated by El Niño from passing over mountains and continuing inland.
Proctor said it meant the warm air mass had lingered over B.C., unable to go east due to high pressure acting like "a wall."
He said Environment Canada's long-term forecast called for more seasonal temperatures to return for the first week of January, bringing potential snowfall to higher elevations in the Interior.
But Proctor said snowfall was less certain for coastal areas in coming weeks, adding that skiers and resorts should temper expectations.
"We may see potential for some snowfall," Proctor says. "But really longer term it does look like an El Niño winter at this point in time, continuing and remaining fairly significant into the early spring."
This report by The Canadian Press was first published Dec. 29, 2023.
Chuck Chiang, The Canadian Press

author: Editorial Team
title: Circle's Revenue Alert: How Fed Rate Cuts Threaten USDC's Stability
text:
The cryptocurrency world is buzzing with a crucial question: how will impending U.S. Federal Reserve interest rate cuts affect major players like Circle? This isn’t just a theoretical debate; it directly impacts Circle’s revenue , especially as the issuer of USDC, one of the leading stablecoins. Recent insights from Omar, a Director at Dragonfly, shed light on a potentially significant challenge facing the stablecoin giant. This analysis offers a clear look at what the future might hold for the prominent stablecoin issuer .
What Does This Mean for Circle’s Revenue ? Omar’s analysis, shared on X, highlights a stark reality for rate-sensitive companies like Circle. A 100-basis-point cut in U.S. interest rates could have a substantial ripple effect on the company’s financials. Why does this matter so much? Stablecoin issuers like Circle earn a significant portion of their income from holding reserves, often in short-term U.S. Treasury bills, which yield interest.
Here’s a breakdown of the potential financial hit:
Gross Revenue Reduction: A 100-basis-point cut could reduce Circle’s run-rate gross revenue by an estimated $618 million, representing a 23% drop. Gross Profit Decline: The impact extends to profitability, with gross profit potentially falling by $303 million, a 30% decrease. Margin Compression: Operating margins could also see a squeeze, decreasing by 3.3 percentage points. This detailed breakdown provides a clear picture of the financial pressures Fed rate cuts could impose on a company heavily reliant on interest income from its reserves.
How Will the USDC Impact Play Out? To offset the projected revenue loss from lower interest rates, Omar estimates that the supply of USDC would need to increase dramatically. Specifically, the USDC impact necessitates an additional $28 billion in supply to reach a break-even point. This represents a substantial 44% increase over today’s approximately $64 billion USDC circulation.
Achieving such growth in USDC supply is a significant undertaking, especially in a competitive stablecoin market. It underscores the challenge of maintaining profitability when a core revenue stream is under pressure. For any stablecoin issuer , diversifying revenue becomes paramount in such an environment. The road ahead for growth will require strategic maneuvers.
How is Circle Adapting to the New Crypto Finance Landscape? Understanding these potential headwinds, Circle has already begun implementing strategic maneuvers. The recent $1.5 billion share sale, which occurred just yesterday according to Omar, can be seen as a proactive measure to shore up capital. This move is critical as the company navigates a period of likely Fed rate cuts . This capital infusion provides a cushion against potential revenue shortfalls.
Furthermore, Circle is actively pushing to launch new products designed to monetize transaction flow rather than solely relying on interest income from reserves. Initiatives like the Circle Payments Network (CPN) and Circle Chain are examples of this strategic shift. These platforms aim to generate revenue through transaction fees and services, creating more resilient and diversified income streams in the evolving landscape of crypto finance . This strategic pivot is essential for long-term sustainability and maintaining Circle’s revenue .
In conclusion, while the prospect of U.S. Fed rate cuts presents a clear challenge to Circle’s revenue model, the company is not standing still. Through capital raises and innovative product development focused on transaction monetization, Circle is actively working to mitigate the impact and ensure its continued growth as a leading stablecoin issuer. The ability to adapt to changing economic conditions will be crucial for its future success in the dynamic crypto space.
Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) 1. How do Fed rate cuts specifically affect stablecoin issuers like Circle? Stablecoin issuers often hold a significant portion of their reserves in interest-bearing assets like short-term U.S. Treasury bills. When the Federal Reserve cuts interest rates, the yield on these assets decreases, directly reducing the interest income that stablecoin issuers, including Circle, earn on their reserves.
2. What specific financial impact could Circle face from lower interest rates? According to a Dragonfly director, a 100-basis-point cut could reduce Circle’s run-rate gross revenue by $618 million (23%), gross profit by $303 million (30%), and operating margins by 3.3 percentage points. This highlights the significant potential USDC impact on the company’s financials.
3. How much would USDC supply need to grow to offset revenue loss from rate cuts? To break even and offset the projected revenue loss from lower interest rates, the supply of USDC would need to increase by an estimated $28 billion. This represents a substantial 44% increase over its current circulation, posing a significant growth challenge for the stablecoin issuer .
4. What strategies is Circle employing to counter the impact of rate cuts? Circle is implementing several strategies, including a recent $1.5 billion share sale to raise capital. Additionally, the company is focusing on launching new products like the Circle Payments Network (CPN) and Circle Chain, which aim to monetize transaction flow and diversify its revenue streams beyond interest income from reserves.
5. What are Circle Payments Network (CPN) and Circle Chain? The Circle Payments Network (CPN) and Circle Chain are new product initiatives by Circle designed to generate revenue through transaction fees and services. These platforms aim to facilitate payment flows and build out blockchain infrastructure, contributing to Circle’s diversification in the broader crypto finance ecosystem.
Share Your Thoughts! Did this analysis on Circle’s revenue and the impact of Fed rate cuts resonate with you? Share this article on your social media platforms to spark a conversation about the future of stablecoins and crypto finance!
To learn more about the latest explore our article on key developments shaping the crypto market , including the future of stablecoins and their institutional adoption.

author: 112 Cantabria
title: Liébana y la Cantabria del Ebro estarán el sábado en aviso amarillo por lluvia y tormentas
text:
El Servicio de Emergencias 112 del Gobierno de Cantabria recomienda extremar la prudencia ya que la Agencia Estatal de Meteorología (AEMET) ha activado los avisos amarillos por lluvia y tormentas para el sábado, día 10 de mayo.
La meteorología adversa se iniciará a las 13:00 horas y se extenderá hasta las 20:00 horas. Se esperan acumulaciones de 15 litros por metro cuadrado en una hora, tormentas y no se descarta granizo.
Recomendaciones
Ante este episodio el 112 recomienda retirar del exterior de las viviendas aquellos objetos que puedan ser arrastrados por el agua; revisar canalones y desagües; no estacionar vehículos en cauces secos ni a la orilla de ríos; circular, en la medida de lo posible, por carreteras principales y autopistas, y aumentar la prudencia al volante.
En el caso de encontrarse en campo abierto al inicio de una tormenta, es necesario buscar un lugar en el que cobijarse, como un coche o un edificio, evitando permanecer al aire libre. En el caso de estar lejos de un refugio adecuado, se insta a los ciudadanos a mantenerse alejado de masas de agua y de zonas altas, se deben de buscar lugares bajos o una depresiones del terreno y no tumbarse en el suelo. Además, nunca hay que refugiarse debajo de árboles, en particular si están aislados, y es conveniente alejarse de alambradas, verjas, vías del tren y otros objetos metálicos, al igual que de zonas ricas en mineral de hierro.
En casa se recomienda evitar corrientes de aire, ya que atraen los rayos, cerrando puertas y ventanas. Durante la tormenta se deben de evitar los baños y las duchas, ya que el agua es una buena conductora de la electricidad. Es conveniente, también, proteger los electrodomésticos desenchufando aquellos que se pueda, para evitar que sean dañados por una subida de tensión o que ocasionen descargas eléctricas.
Además, se insta a la ciudadanía a que ante cualquier incidencia llame lo antes posible al 112 para procurar una rápida intervención. Además, a quienes tienen cuenta en redes sociales, se les anima a seguir los perfiles oficiales de entidades que facilitan información sobre emergencias, estado de las carreteras o meteorología.
¿Desea recibir notificaciones cuando se publica algo nuevo?
